Summary: Do not stay here in the summer. There are millions of ants. We left for a few hours and came back and they were swarming inside of our motorhome. 48 hour later and we are still trying to kill ants. Left immediately but the Ranger tells us that this is a problem and you can buy diatomaceous earth at the host which is kind of a silly thing to have to do when you’re camping. He said well bugs are part of the camping experience-not for us!

Parked my camper there the first night, and arrived back from an event the next day to find hundreds of ants in my camper.  The next morning, there were literally THOUSANDS of ants in my camper.  The park host apparently sells diatomaceous earth that prevents ants from entering your space, though is useless once they're in your unit.  No one mentions this at check-in ..

Summary Heading: Sweet spot for a swell campout
Summary: Great place to dig in for the night for an early morning swell chase. The only problem is that it is definitely not 1 $ sign. $40 for the night is not cheap camping. Yeah they have showers and restrooms (which are really well kept). But that's not my complaint. Rangers on point, great vibe. Each site has it's own fire pit... it's just the price. The only place to camp in the area (San O) is closed during Cali swell months (winter) and they only charge a fraction of what San M Cmp grounds charges, but bc they are closed you are forced to pay arm and leg for a spot a few miles down the road. I personally could do without the amenities bc I go down solo for the surf, but dude... $40 is $40 for a. single night. It would be cool if they offered a pass for the year or a way to get a

Summary Heading: Popular with surfers but a bit strange
Summary: We camped there in mid/late September. Lots of rabbits, coyotes, and *ants* which climbed up the tires and stabilizers of our little RV and quickly infested us! It's a bit of a journey to the beach, which was nice enough, but we were trying to visit San Diego/Coronado, so it was a bit of a drive there. It was lonely at our time of year. I think all the Californians know which state parks are the best and quickly claim them.

Summary Heading: 5 stars if you are a surfer and there's swell
Summary: I went there to surf, and I camped so I could surf in the a.m. and p.m.  The campground was fine.  Bathrooms were clean enough, the showers required token.  It was quiet at night.  There is not an ocean view, cuz you're a little over the top of the hill from the ocean. Reservations at this campground include access to San Onofre State Beach, so if you stay a night, you can surf in the evening, and then you can have access the entire next day.  I rode my bike to Upper Trestles, and I drove to San Onofre.  Both spots had good waves, but the crowds are heavy with a mid-summer 3-6 foot swell.   There were a lot of rabbits running around, and it seemed most spots had families staying in them.  I saw kids riding bikes and skateboards around the campground.  The weather was really fine

I have been camping here with my family for almost 2 decades. Being married to a surfer and this being the best place to camp to be near Trestles, it has been a favorite for us. The sites are spacious with large hedges for privacy. Please be aware, the beach is about 1.5 miles from the campground. My only gripe is now you cannot check in before 2:00 now, even if your site is empty. We have always been able to check in early here, so this new policy stinks.

I don't think you can do much better in an urban area.  The beach is great, and the site is pleasant, and you are basically at the beach.  San Onofre is nearby, but there is more freeway noise.  Doheny is nearby, but it is really tough to secure a spot.

Summary Heading: Backup for San Clemente state beach camping
Summary: Typical high California campground price of 65 per night water and electricity. Make reservations early. Bushes give you more privacy than at San Clemente state park but you are inland a couple miles instead of being next to the ocean. We stayed two nights before we moved to San Clemente state beach.

Very nice campground. Pretty quiet. No loud partiers were here. Everyone was very nice. Beware no real wifi. Only place you could get slow wifi was at guard shack. Also the beach is a pretty good hike. I enjoyed it. Part dirt road and part asphalt road. You see a lot of surfers coming back from the beach. Most park on a street not too far from campground. It is worth the hike to be at Tressles. Very few people just surfers. Dogs are supposed to be on leash at all times. My dog obeys well and I never had him on a leash. No one complained but again i did NOT let my dig just roam into other campsites. This is a nice little campground and would do it again. Nothing fancy. Showers cost money but it is nominal and showers were great. You only need 2 tokens at most for a shower.

This was my first time camping , and I did not know what to expect.  But I was surprised how nice the facility was. The weather wAs great, I don’t do well in high heat , so the weather in this month was very good warm enough in the day to go enjoy the beach and cool enough in the night to enjoy a campfire. We rented an RV for the kids and the adults rented. We got one of the bigger spots next to the restroom so it was really convenient. With the RV rental we hardly saw the kids. The would come out to ride their scooters and eat and then come out at night to roast marshmallows. The beach is not walking distance, but the campground gets you free parking at the beach . On sat the parking at the beach is a nightmare but the others days were not too bad. The beach is really rocky ,

Summary Heading: Clean and Spacious Camping Close to the Beach
Summary: Each site at this campground is very spacious so you never feel too close to your neighbors. The bathrooms are stocked and generally very clean. You will need coins for the showers. There are electrical outlets in the bathrooms.    The site is across the freeway from the beach so you will either need to bike or drive to get to the beach.  You could walk but it would be a long walk and potentially tricky if lugging a lot of gear.    The campground backs up to Camp Pendelton so be prepared to hear machine guns, and military operations going on all hours of the day. It costs $15 to park per car; they take cash or card.

Summary Heading: A little tattered and a neglected
Summary: We camp camp on average about twice a year and always have a good time. The short. Price availability leads to a lot of riff-raft in the park so keep your bikes locked up and valuables out of site after hours.   When we were there in May of this year I went use the restroom and there was a guy that had just passed out on the sidewalk outside the rest room (11:00 PM) and when I went there in the AM he was still in the same spot so there isn't much security going on after 10 PM and the gates are wide open.   The facilities are pretty slim, rest rooms and showers mostly and besides the amphitheater there isn't much for the kids to do unless you're planning on going to the beach. The walk to the beach is a challenge as well so, if you're taking little ones you might consider and day

We stayed here mid-week in June 2017.  The campground was not full but it is well-used.  The hike to Trestles surfing beach is 1.8 miles, not 1.5 miles as stated some places.  We walked there and rode bikes but it's not for swimming.  However, your camping permits get you free parking at San Clemente State Beach up the road.   You can also visit the Bluffs campground and beaches.  We tried Trails 2, 3, and 6.  Only 6 had a swimming beach with a lifeguard.   Otherwise the beach is mostly dense cobblestones that could break an ankle.  The sound of war games from Camp Pendleton was a curious effect but the campsites are very pleasant and seem always available during the week.  We liked the ones located on the outer edges. We would certainly visit again.

There are a lot of positives about this place. Our site (#134 this time but we've stayed in other areas, too) was private, quiet, near the toilets/showers and came with a delightful abundance of rock squirrels, bunnies, the occasional lizard, wrentits, towhees and crows. Vultures, too, but we won't go there. The paved road and site pads were in good condition as was the fire ring. The picnic table has had a lot of use. The showers are turbo-charged. Keep your tender bits out of the direct stream. I like this CG better than the beach ones because it's less damp, sunnier and not so windy.  It's a nice walk to the beach from camp. You get the occasional muffled serenade from the troops at Camp P next door but that wasn't bothersome.  Next to zero road noise.  What could've been

Memorial Day weekend was supposedly sold out but I could see sites not being used. Stayed in spot 21 electric & water hook ups. Had another family meet us out there and they stayed in a large tent (20x10?). Had plenty of room for our 19' trailer, tables, chairs, my pickup and their Excursion.   Used the fire pit one night - each site has one. Surprised we could use actual wood in southern California.   There are bigger sites in the middle, if you plan ahead, other families had huge set ups between sites that backed up to each other. It is more open that way and our site was much more secluded. Depends upon preference.  Cool spin was astronomy night with volunteers and their giant telescopes.  Went to the beach one day. You can ride bikes or drive. Don't pack a lot because it's

Our immediate reaction to seeing our site was disappointment.  The site lacked level ground for pitching our tent, it was dirty and dusty, the picnic table was in state of advanced dilapidation, the bathrooms had no mirrors nor did they have lights, and the showers required quarters.  We've camped in California state parks before and enjoyed the experience, so I hope that San Mateo is an anomaly.  And at $35.00 a night, that was a high price to pay for a run-down campsite.  Should anyone ask if I would recommend staying here, two words will suffice as an answer: Absolutely not!

With a short bike ride (a tad challenging for some) to the beach this campground is a great choice if you cannot get into the campground on the beach. The area is a lot of dirt, but the bathrooms are clean. The atmosphere makes you feels as if you are really far from reality when you actually are not. The ants were a pain, but as long as you bring ant spray you should be fine.  There is not a store on site, they only sell firewood, so make sure you bring everything you need.

Since this is so convenient and close, I really wanted to like this place. But actually, it kinda sucks. Lots of dirt, not close to the water really, $35 for dry camping, the sites are not only close together but awkwardly laid out so that everyone is in your face. I will admit to being a bit sound sensitive, but having SO many kids around me was disturbing. There were 27 tents within 100 yards of my RV. 27! It is like every site is in a mob, so you are encircled. Kids are kids, they're loud by nature. And out camping they should be able to run and scream and play. But 6am is kinda early for that. But, no worries, the artillery at Pendleton started up about then, so the kids just sorta blended into the general din. No trees, really, just sorta scrub oak and brush. Very dusty and

The property is not far off the 5 freeway on the south edge of San Clemente.  Great area for entertainment, food, shopping, and beach.   Sites are spaced out fairly well.  No grass or irrigation for grass so it can be quite dusty. Restrooms and showers were kept in adequate condition. The ant problem is something to prepare for.  On my travel trailer I sprayed Black Flag on all tires, jacks, cords, and hoses that touched the ground to prevent the ants from coming in.  That worked fine.  Don't use powdered cleanser etc as it makes a mess.  Over all a good camping experience and I have camped there several times a year.

Went with a large group and we were able to get our spaces grouped together.  The campgrounds were quiet at night (we were probably the loudest group) and the place was relatively clean.  Restrooms and showers all worked adequately.  Rangers were friendly and helpful.  The kids in our group attended some of the kid-activities they provide and had a lot of fun. Just a 2 or 3 minute drive to San Clemente state beach.  had a fun weekend.

This campground is about 1 mile inland from the I 5 freeway. The campsites are very big and clean.  You can actually feel quite secluded Depending on where you place your tent. There is a Big grill and fire ring at each site. Dog friendly with showers and adequate bathroom facilities. There is a nice wilderness path 1.5 mile walk to the beautiful beach of San Clemente. There is a creek that runs near the campsite but with the California drought it is completely dry. Bugs were not a problem.  Good alternative if you can't get a campsite closer to shoreline.

We stayed here for an overnight to break up a longer trip. The staff was very friendly and the campgrounds were good size. The bathrooms were in good shape also. There are some nice trails to walk or ride to the beach. Dogs are not allowed on some trails and some beaches close bye. We will stay here again!!!

I stayed here with my family and 2 friends.  I have a 31' trailer with 2 slides.  I booked a spot that should have been big enough.  When we arrived it was a bit tight backing into the spot.  I backed all the way into our spot.  Unfortunately the spot we were assigned had 3' wood posts all around the site.  I had to pull my trailer forward and shift it over just to get my slides out.  By doing this I eliminated my vehicle parking spot.  The electric and water is close by so hooking up is easy.  Remember they do not have sewer hook ups but the do have a dump site. The site came with a fire pit and a picnic table.  The fire pit was nice a big and it came with a grate that you could put on to for cooking.  The picnic table was not so inviting.  I looked under the table and it was

Really when it comes to camping, the experience is what you make of it. But as far as providing a great setting, there's nothing special about San Mateo. I'd use it as a last resort if you get shut out of the San Clemente State Beach campground. The good news is, it's only about 10 minutes away if you want to take day trips to the beach. Btw-your receipt you tape to your window for the campground also works as a day pass to the State Beach Day-use area. So don't double pay.   The main reason it gets 2 stars instead of 3 is the serious ant issue. They will invade, armies of them. So I suggest you use airtight coolers, clean up promptly after every meal, and even use your vehicle as a "bear box" for food. Since we're in a drought, the ants are also looking for moisture. So pack

This is a great camp site, that explains why it gets booked so fast. My family and I we're lucky to have found a camp site that was canceled by another family. The kids loved riding bikes and walking to the beach. The camp site is very safe and the restrooms / showers are super clean. Remember to bring dollars for the change machine. Bring plenty of wood, because the sun drops really fast.

A couple of my friends and I booked a spot here for three days, two nights for a friends birthday. The two girls I went with had been there before, I had not. I figured it was already a good sign that this is a campground that my friends enjoy returning to and I was right. The campsite was $35/night and an extra car was $15/day which seemed expensive but is kind of the state park standard. The girl that helped me at the front was very kind and even told me about the area and weather.  The campsite was clean. A wooden picnic table and fire pit are provided. We were really close to the restrooms and showers which was nice for us but I could see how it might be a pain if the grounds were busier. The showers are token operated and there is a machine that exchanges dollar bills (only

Summary Heading: A rustic campground near a rocky beach
Summary: We stayed at this campground in early October, 2014. It is a very rustic and brushy campground. There were not many campers in the park at the time and when we saw the prices, we knew why. The price for our motorhome was $60.00 a night and did not include sewer. There were ants everywhere and the only thing we could see that would make others stay there was the camp's close proximity to the ocean. (about two miles) I would only stay here again if I could not find anything else. (typical California high prices)

Summary Heading: Example of drought damage and bad service
Summary: Dry and dusty. A surprising $15/day parking fee for 2nd and 3rd car. One State employee is anti-consumer: He made two registered campers' cars wait 12 minutes at the gate until he checked in another vehicle, rather than allow the registered campers to use the 2nd lane for its intended purpose. Lots of noise from I-5 plus ants.  Not recommended unless you're a glutton for punishment.

We checked into the campground on 9/9/14. We already had a site (88) reserved for three nights that would handle 8 people and three cars.. When we arrived we were told that two of the cars must pay $15/each/day. Big surprise. So, we had four cars, and decided to just get another site close by, and have two people and two cars at the new site #87. We could only have the new site on day by day basis. We had to pay the normal site fee plus an admin fee too plus the $15/day for the extra car. We had to pay before noon each day, still not knowing, if would loose the site do to their reservation system, which truly sucks. Well, it happened on the third night we had to move our site, because the site was reserved over the internet. Needless to say we were very pissed off, and packed up

Summary Heading: To anyone who doesn't find this place amazing.
Summary: This campground is amazing. True there aren't very many trees but that's why you go for a walk down to the beach and hang out there all day instead of just sitting around your campsite, also bring your own source of shading; a tarp or a pop up canopy, it will help when you are at your campsite. Yes there is wildlife, it's called being out doors if you don't like bugs, animals, dirt, or fresh air then maybe this place may not be for you. I would stay here over and over again. Bring some fun outdoor activities like a Frisbee or football, a bike, surfboard, boogie board, whatever your heart desires. I highly recommend this place I've been coming here since I was little and I am so happy my parents took us all the time, we have had some of the most amazing times here, It's great for

Summary Heading: Near the beach; clean and well-run, but not the most beautiful
Summary: You just need to know what you're getting at this campground.  You are getting a clean, well-run campground near the beach. The location is very accessible, near the 5 freeway and not far from a convenience market. Conversely, it's well isolated from any adjacent development so you don't feel like you're camping near a motel or strip mall.  You are not getting a beachfront location. It's a nice hike (2 miles?) to the sand, but you might drive if you need to haul a bunch of beach stuff. The nearby beaches are very nice.  You are not getting lush green grounds or much deep shade; it's a lot of dry, hardpack dirt and few large trees. Privacy between spaces is pretty average. You are also not getting away from civilization since you can see and hear Camp Pendleton (boom!)  The size

We loved the campground.  It was quiet, clean, friendly people.  The hike to the beach is a nice hike and the beach is beautiful.  Fire rings were great, nice picnic tables and there are plenty of trees and shrubs to give privacy from other sites.  The whole campground is well maintained and you can tell they take pride in their facilities.  We will definitely be back, it is such an easy place to get to!

This campground is near, but not on the beach.  You can see Camp Pendleton from the sites.  We knew that before we went; so, we were not disappointed.  The sites have plenty of trees and shrubs to give you some privacy from other sites.  We stayed in site 50 and it was very spacious and private.  We took the 1.5 mile walk to Trestles beach.  It is a surf beach with no facilities.  I don't recommend it for families.  We decided to drive to San Clemente beach for the day and had a great time.  I gave it four stars because of the ants.  Beware, the ants will invade.  I was suspicious upon arrival when I saw the white chalk outline where the last camper's tires use to be.  I read that salt will keep them out, but these ants still found a way.  Those little pests walked right up our

Summary Heading: Where to begin.......will never stay here again.
Summary: First of all, there is NO grass!  Few trees, all dirt, no shade.  This campground has absolutely nothing going for it!  The state should pay campers to stay there, not the other way around.  The crows come to visit in the afternoon and throw berries all over the campsite and vehicles.  The restrooms were nice and clean but there is nothing to do!  Bombs were going off all night and day at nearby Camp Pendleton.  I do not recommend!

We stayed at San Mateo campground aug 16-17, 2013.  We had 2 sites side-by-side and went with another famiy and their children and dog.  If you get the inner-ring - there is TONS of space.  But if you get the outer ring you can barely put a large tent on the site.  The fire rings were great and everything seemed to be nicely run.  That is, until we took showers.  It takes 50 cents for 3 minutes.  Every one of the people in our party ran out of water and with soap filled hair and eyes, deposted another 50 cents and NO WATER came back on.  It was a nightmare.  I have to dress covered in soap and finish washing at the outdoor sink.  They should have better showers if they want people to come back.  Also, the quiet hours are not observed in the morning.  We were woken each morning

Summary Heading: San Mateo Campground For Two Months
Summary: I stayed here for more than two months jumping site to site. The staff and campground are perfect. My kids love to do all the events they do for the youth. Not to far drive from San Clemente, store, bars, food etc..

This was our very first camping experience! Me, a 56 yr old Gramma, my Daughter & Son in-law, my Grandson 6 yr.'s old and Grand babygirl 9 mo's.  We rented an RV through Cruise America ~ it was fantastic! So clean and new and in excellent operating order!  I had read review after review and blog after blog for over 2 months before deciding  on "what and where"... It so paid off! Great sites @ San Mateo ~ we were in ADA site 01 ~  as they are all very roomy and have lush privacy foliage between you and your neighbor, unusual as I have learned, for a "beach camp"...Where you are more likely to be closer and shoulder-to-shoulder w/ neighboring camper. The fire rings were really nice, easy to load up with our wood and if we had run out, the Ranger station had bundles for $6.00. The

Spent 4 days over spring break here with 4 other families. Very clean, wooded campground. Spots were a little smaller than expected, but definitely not a parking lot situation. Kids enjoyed the 2 mile hike to the beach. Clean bathrooms and showers. Big grassy field areas.  Only complaint is no sewer hookup. Only water and power. Also,, very limited cell phone service. Maybe has to do with being so close to camp pendelton.

This campground was awesome!  We stayed here for 5 days in our 5th wheel. Yes, there were squirrels, bunnies, & birds but our 2 dogs kep them all away. We heard the artillery & helicopters at Camp Pendleton but it didn't bother us.   Only 1.5 miles to Trestles Beach!  Also, the San Clemente Beach Walking Trail was spectacular!  Great things to do nearby, beautiful beaches. What's not to love?  Showers & campground were always very clean!!!  Friendly staff & campers. We loved the space between neighbors. Will be back definitely

Summary Heading: Excellent choice for surf/camp road trip if you don't have time to go far
Summary: Stayed here in mid-August and really enjoyed it. Better than the San Clemente campground, which is technically closer to the water but not a surfable beach. San Mateo had larger campsites with trees for privacy and shade in between sites. Closest drive to San Onofre State Beach for surfing, and the $30 you paid for a campsite waives the $15 parking fee at the beach! There are no grills, only firepits, so we brought a spare oven rack which made for a perfect grill. It's also a dog-friendly campground, so our pooch had plenty of company. (San O beach also allows dogs, on leash.) Other reviews complain about squirrels -- bring your dog! We never saw one in our site. The only complaints: they don't have separate areas for RVs and tents. We were lucky the campers near us did not have

Summary Heading: great campsite but watch out for squirrels in vehicle
Summary: We love this camp ground.  Third time coming here.. love it love it..  This time.. squirrels chewed my hubby's engine wires.  A cost we can't afford.. Be careful!  Otherwise, enjoy the site.

Summary Heading: Nice and Clean, but Cold and Noisy!
Summary: My family of nine spent two days at space # 151.  Very large site compared to most.  The bathrooms were nice and clean.  Lots of large bushes everywhere.  Our neighbors on either side had loud music at night and a generator running most of the day that were very annoying.  We slept peacefully, though, once the music was turned off. The weather was chilly!  Would have enjoyed it more if it had been warmer.

Summary Heading: Nice campground but watch out for the squirrels
Summary: My best friend and I took our families camping at this campground based on the great reviews and the location to the beach. The campground was very nice, it was clean. The restrooms were cleaned daily and we always had a hot shower. We got lucky with our site and had a decent sized site. Be careful when you choose your site because we walked around and looked at the sites and some were super small. Had we gotten one of those sites our family would not have fit.  We were unlucky enough to get next to a large family that had tons of kids from baby to teenagers and  they were up at 6:00 am every morning talking like it was the middle of the day!  You can't pick your neighbors, and I guess that's just part of camping.  The reason why I gave this such a low review was because the

My boyfriend and I camped out at San Mateo campground last weekend. We were lucky since our camp spot was big and right next to restroom/ shower. The campground were full at the time we were there. It was clean and organized.   It was a great experience for me. The campsite has indoor hot shower, love it. You will need to pay 50 cent for 2.20 minute (not bad). The restrooms were clean during our stay. I felt safe and was quiet after 10 pm.  Each campsite comes with picnic table, firepit, and small bush/ tress for your privacy. It has beach trail about 1.5 miles to trestle beach.  I will definitely camp there again in the future.

My daughter and I have been camping here  for  quite a few years  when My granddaughters were small I brought them camping here  we started out  in a tent. we camped like that for about 5 years  then we purchased an Rv  so now we camp with the hook ups. We just got back for our 2nd time this summer and were going again next week . Loved  the camp ground  people are considerate had nothing stolen. and close drive to the beaches.   I would recommend this to anyone. showers and bathrooms are clean.

Summary Heading: Much to do at San Onofre State Beach
Summary: I just camped out at San Mateo Campground Aug 18th to 20th ‘08. I took all the neighborhood kids, many of them are on the High School Surf Team and we all loved every minute of it. We had to reserve two different spots #122 and #103 both nice and we couldn’t see our neighbors due to the dense bushes around these spots. I recommend spots from about #101 through #114 or so, these have more bushes and trees. Lots of things to do here, I’ve seen everything from rattlesnakes to a bald eagle at this campground. The place is covered with California Native Plants, several different types of Sage and California Buckwheat, Elderberries (these make a good pie), bladderpod (Indians used to eat these)...just to name a few–many of these plants attract the many birds that can be found here,

Summary Heading: A great value in So Cal
Summary: My family and I were looking for a quick get away near Orange County and we found it. I must admit I was concerned when I read several bad reviews ranging from too much noise to stolen articles. San Mateo is located off the 5fwy and Exit Cristianitos. Camp Pendleton Marines actually own the property but camping is open to the public. Our experience was in San Mateo's RV loop which I believe is spaces 1-60. We stayed in space 48 and found the site clean and spacious by coastal RV site standards. The RV site provides water hookup and 20-30 amp electrical service, fire pit and a dump station at the front of the park. For around $29 per night it was well worth it. The surroundings were lush greenery, hiking trails and the famed Trestles surf beach 1 1/2 mi away (hiking distance) The

We have stayed at the San Mateo Campground in the past and it has been fine. This time we were disappointed to discover that there is no one there to check anyone in during the evening hours. We arrived around 7:00 p.m. both nights this past week. Although we booked our reservations through the website and had our confirmation numbers with us, no one was there to check; also there was no one there at 6:00 a.m. when we left to go to the beach to surf. Therefore, we did not get the necessary sticker for our windshield to produce at the other State Parks the next day and we ended up paying an additional $10.00 fee.    Upon arriving at our site the 2nd night, we found someone in our site. We drove all over the campground, in our motorhome, looking for a Ranger or someone to help us.

The campground itself is descent, typical so cal desert camping, but it ts literally only one mile off the freeway so if you want to feel like "you are getting away from it all" this is definitly not the place.  The inner loop is basically like a large group campground.  There is NO privacy between the campgrounds that back each other.  My real complaint has to do with the campground guests who thought staying up until 3 am screaming profanities at each other was an ideal vacation.  My husband and I ended up packing up everything at 3am and heading home because we couldn't sleep at all with all the noise.  No exaggeration, they were still going strong when we drove out.  Did we seek help from the campground or sheriff whose number was posted on the ranger station?  Of course,

I haven't been camping since I was a kid myself. I wanted to take my sons (hubby's idea of camping is no room service) and maybe see if they enjoyed it.  I rented a tent trailer and headed off....... We all enjoyed the campground, was VERY clean, the boys enjoyed the wildlife (rabbits, ground squirrels, birds), and the bathrooms were clean along with the showers.    Since its a State Park, we could go to San Clemente to boogie board and swim or to Doheny Beach at no entrance charge.  Then go back to the campground for the rest of the evening.  Was pretty quiet, concidering I rented a TENT trailer, I felt very safe there, security came around couple times that I saw, and our neighbors were very conciderate to the rules and kept things down after 11pm.  I would recommend this

Summary Heading: Great Campground but Check the Cost.
Summary: Nearly every year my family camps out at one of the local campsites here in California and many friends join us as well.  We have been to San Mateo Campground (SMC)  before and this time (August 2006) is a return visit.   We camp for 3 nights each time. The campground is well kept, very clean with lots of shade on most campsites.  Although SMC is well secluded, one thing that we find very convenient is the closeness to civilization.  A short trip of 1.5 mi and you're in San Clemente with plenty of shopping, restaurants and beaches. This all sounds real good but I must warn you of soething I feel is deceptive in the posted cost for the campsites. Two years ago we paid $25 per site per night.  This year we paid $27.50.  Not a bad increase, but although they claim 3 cars per
